docs.text: Welcome to My Personal Website About Me Hi, I'm Hoang Nguyen, a computational biochemist, data scientist, lecturer and learner. Skills Data science : Anaconda, Kubernetes, Docker, Airflow, AWS Prgramming : Python, R, Rust, C# Machine Learning : PyTorch, Keras, TensorFlow Others skills: HTML/CSS, LaTeX Play with Data I enjoy sharing my knowledge and experiences through blog posts. Check out some of my latest entries: Computational Science If you are new to computational science, these blog posts would be useful to you. Contact Feel free to reach out to me via email or connect with me on LinkedIn .

docs.text: Experience Teaching Wellington Institute of Technology (WelTec) | Wellington, New Zealand Lecturer | 02/2023 - Present Teaching Courses : Mathematics for IT (IT5501) Data Analysis and Visualisation (DS6502) Data Mining Tools and Techniques (DS6503) Web Application Development (SD7501) Intelligent System Development (SD7502) Mobile Application Development (SD6501) Victoria University of Wellington (VUW) | Wellington, New Zealand Tutor | 2020 - 2022 Teaching Courses : Techniques of Data Science (DATA 201) Simulation and Stochastic Models (DATA 474/DATA 304/COMP 312) Research Wellington Institute of Technology (WelTec) | Wellington, New Zealand Co-Principal Investigator | 02/2023 - Present Project : Systematic review on Human-Computer Interaction and Artificial Intelligence for healthcare Project : Developing deep learning models to predict drug-target binding affinity Victoria University of Wellington (VUW) | Wellington, New Zealand Research Assistant | 2019 - 2022 Project : Discovery of novel selective kinase inhibitors using deep learning Project : Develop a framework for drug profiling Project : Phenotypic drug discovery using deep learning Computational Biology Center, IU, Vietnam National University | Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam Researcher | 2015 - 2019 Project : Generic multi-task learning framework for structural mixed data using deep neural network feature sharing architecture -- Application to predictive tasks in Vietnamese herbal medicine. Project : Knowledge discovery in Vietnamese herbal medicine by use of VIETHERB. Project : Building Vietnamese herbal database towards big data science in nature-based medicine.

docs.text: Data Analysis For You Hey! I hope you enjoy applying data analysis skills and techniques to discover data stories. I write these blogs as a guideline for beginners as well as for myself to recall knowledge. If you're an expert, these blogs may not be for you. What You Need When I write my blogs, I assume that you have basic statistics knowledge and R-programming skills. You may need to download and install RStudio . What to Expect The blogs contain as little theory as possible with plain and simple explanations to get you straight to the point. You are expected to know how to code and interpret results after each topic. Let's Play Linear Model Simple Linear Regression Multiple Linear Regression Generalized Linear Model Logistic Regression Comparing two means One-sample t-Test Independent t-Test Paired-sample t-Test z-Test Analysis of Variance Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA) Multivariate Analysis of Variance (MANOVA) Multivariate Analysis of Covariance (MANCOVA) Post-hoc Analysis Comparing two proportions Chi-square Test p-Test
docs.title: Data Analysis

docs.text: Simple Linear Regression Purpose Simple linear regression is used to analyze the relationship between two variables: a predictor variable ( x ) and a response variable ( y ), this post is for you. Visualization 1. Simple visualization Visualize relationship between Women Height ( women$height ) and Women Weight ( women$weight ) #svg("women_plot.svg", width = 6, height = 6) #set up figure's size plot(women$height, women$weight, main = "Height vs Weight for American Women", xlab = "Height (inches)", # y-axis label ylab = "Weight (pounds)", # y-axis label pch = 16, # point size col = "blue") # color abline(lm(weight ~ height, data = women), col = "red", lwd = 2) # red regression line #dev.off() #export Note : In R, $ means of dataframe . women$height means taking height variable (column) from dataframe women . Here what you'll get 2. Visualization with ggplot2 library Visualize relationship between Women Height ( women$height ) and Women Weight ( women$weight ) library(ggplot2) # Create the plot p <- ggplot(women, aes(x = height, y = weight)) + geom_point(color = "blue", size = 1) + # blue points (pch = 16 equivalent) geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "red", se = FALSE, linewidth = 1) + # red regression line labs(title = "Height vs Weight for American Women", # main title x = "Height (inches)", # x-axis label y = "Weight (pounds)") + # y-axis label theme_minimal() #ggsave("women_plot.svg", plot = p, width = 4.5, height = 4.5, units = "in", device = "svg") # Export as SVG Here what you'll get Hypothesis testing 1. Test of signficance Use cor.test() function to test the signicance of hypothesis. cor.test(women$height, women$weight) Note : Linear regression assumes a linear relationship between variables. We should verify both that the variables are correlated and that their relationship is indeed linear. Here are results from the script above: Pearson's product-moment correlation data: women$height and women$weight t = 37.855, df = 13, p-value = 1.091e-14 alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 0.9860970 0.9985447 sample estimates: cor 0.9954948 2. Result interpretation cor = 0.9954948 => Correlation coefficient ( r ) > 0.99 => Very high positive correlation p-value = 1.091e-14 < 0.05 (commonly used significance level) => Statistically significant correlation 95%CI = (0.9861, 0.9985) => We are 95% confident that the true population correlation coefficient lies between 0.9861 and 0.9985. The grey region represents the confidence interval for the regression line. In geom_smooth() , set se = TRUE to display the confidence interval for the regression line. library(ggplot2) # Create the plot p <- ggplot(women, aes(x = height, y = weight)) + geom_point(color = "blue", size = 1) + # blue points (pch = 16 equivalent) geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "red", se = TRUE, linewidth = 1) + # red regression line labs(title = "Height vs Weight for American Women", # main title x = "Height (inches)", # x-axis label y = "Weight (pounds)") + # y-axis label theme_minimal()

docs.text: Data Mining For You Hey! I hope you enjoy applying data mining skills and techniques to discover hidden patterns and insights from data. I write these blogs as a guideline for beginners as well as for myself to recall knowledge. If you're an expert, these blogs may not be for you. What You Need When I write my blogs, I assume that you have basic statistics knowledge and Python programming skills. You may need to download and install Anaconda (which includes Jupyter Notebook) or use Google Colab for cloud-based analysis. What to Expect The blogs contain as little theory as possible with plain and simple explanations to get you straight to the point. You are expected to know how to code and interpret results after each topic. Let's Play 1. Predictive Analysis Regression Analysis Polynomial Regression Ridge Regression Lasso Regression Support Vector Regression (SVR) Classification Analysis Decision Trees (DT) Random Forests (RF) Support Vector Machines (SVM) K-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) Anomaly Detection Statistical Outlier Detection Isolation Forest Local Outlier Factor (LOF) One-Class SVM 2. Association Rule Mining Market Basket Analysis Apriori Algorithm FP-Growth Algorithm 3. Dimensionality Reduction Principal Component Analysis (PCA) Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) t-SNE 4. Clustering Analysis K-Means Clustering Hierarchical Clustering DBSCAN Clustering 5. Time-series Analysis Time Series Basics and Visualization Moving Averages ARIMA Modeling Seasonal Decomposition Time Series Forecasting

docs.text: Machine Learning For You Hey! I hope you enjoy applying machine learning algorithms and techniques to build predictive models and solve real-world problems. I write these blogs as a guideline for beginners as well as for myself to recall knowledge. If you're an expert, these blogs may not be for you. What You Need When I write my blogs, I assume that you have basic statistics knowledge and Python programming skills. You may need to download and install Anaconda (which includes Jupyter Notebook) or use Google Colab for cloud-based analysis. What to Expect The blogs contain as little theory as possible with plain and simple explanations to get you straight to the point. You are expected to know how to code and interpret results after each topic. Let's Play 1. Supervised Learning Tree-Based Methods Decision Trees Random Forest Boosting (AdaBoost) Gradient Boosting Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) Instance-Based Methods K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) Naive Bayes Distance-Based Methods Support Vector Machine (SVM) Support Vector Regression (SVR) 2. Unsupervised Learning Clustering Algorithms K-Means Clustering Hierarchical Clustering DBSCAN Clustering Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) Dimensionality Reduction Principal Component Analysis (PCA) Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) t-SNE UMAP 3. Model Evaluation and Selection Feature Engineering Feature Scaling Feature Encoding Feature Creation Model Validation Train-Test Split Cross-Validation Bootstrap Sampling Performance Metrics Regression Metrics Classification Metrics Confusion Matrix ROC Curve and AUC Model Optimization Hyperparameter Tuning Grid Search Random Search Feature Selection 4. Specialized Topics Neural Networks Perceptron Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) Backpropagation Time Series Forecasting Time Series Preprocessing Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) Models Machine Learning for Time Series Ensemble Learning Strategy Bagging Boosting Stacking Voting Classifiers Blending
